questions.title: Passage Ⅰ
questions.article:
Scientists examined a continuous 40,000-year fossil record of a snail species that lives today on Bonin Island in the Pacific Ocean. Fossil snail shells, along with living snails' shells, were studied to determine how the snails have changed over time.

Twenty complete fossil snail shells were randomly extracted from each rock layer on the island. The shells were cleaned, photographed, and measured. A small piece of each shell was used to determine the shell's age by radiocarbon dating.

Study 1
Living snails had dark-colored stripes on their light-colored shells. The stripes on the fossil shells were not vis­ible to the naked eye, but could be seen when the shells were viewed under ultraviolet light. The pattern of stripes on each shell was recorded, starting at the top of the shell. Any stripe having a width less than the height of the shell was called a line (L) and any stripe exactly the height of the shell or wider was called a band (B). The ages of the shells and the percent of the shells of each age with a given pattern of stripes are shown in Table 1.


Study 2
The number of whorls (turns of the shell as viewed from above), the inner lip length, and the diameter of the shell were measured for each shell (see Figure 1).


The average of each of the 3 geometric characteristics for shells of a given age was calculated. These results are shown in Figure 2.




Table and figures adapted from Satoshi Chiba, "A 40,000-year Record of Discontinuous Evolution of Island Snails." ©1996 by The Paleontological Society.
questions.question: 1.  According to the results of Study 2, the average shell diameter of fossil snail shells with an age of 30,000 years is closest to which of the following?

questions.question: 2.  Suppose, in Study 1, the scientists had determined that the age of fossil snail shells taken from a particular rock layer on the island  was 31,000 years. Based on the results of Study 1, the stripe pattern percents for that group of shells would most likely have been clos­est to which of the following?

questions.question: 3.  Which of the following statements best describes how Study 1 differed from Study 2 ?

choices.A: In Study 1, changes in 3 geometric characteristics of snail shells were studied; but in Study 2, the environment in which the snails lived was studied.
choices.B: In Study 1, changes in 3 geometric characteristics of snail shells were studied; but in Study 2, the variation in the pattern of  stripes on snail shells was studied.
choices.C: In Study 1, the variation in the pattern of stripes on snail shells was studied; but in Study 2, the environment in which the snails lived was studied.
choices.D: In Study 1, the variation in the pattern of stripes on snail shells was studied; but in Study 2, changes in 3 geometric characteristics of snail shells were studied.

questions.question: 4.  Based on the  description of the procedures fo the stud­ies, the scientists had to extract complete and  intact fossil snail shells instead of fossil shell fragments from the rock layers in order to:

choices.A: describe the colors of a living snail's shell.
choices.B: make accurate measurements of each shell's dimensions.
choices.C: determine the present-day climate of Bonin Island.
choices.D: determine the rock layers' ages using radiocarbon dating.

questions.article:

questions.question: 6.  According to the results of Study 2, how do the aver­age number of whorls and the average shell diameter for living Bonin Island snails compare to those of fossil Bonin Island snails with an age of 40,000 years? For the living snails:

choices.A: both the average number of whorls and the average shell diameter are larger.
choices.B: both the average number of whorls and the average shell diameter are smaller.
choices.C: the average number of whorls is larger and the average shell diameter is smaller.
choices.D: the average number of whorls is smaller and the average shell diameter is larger.

questions.title: Passage Ⅱ
questions.article:
Most fruit flies have red eyes; some have white eyes. One gene that affects eye color is located on the X chroma­ some. Female offspring receive 1 X chromosome from both their mother and their father, so they have 2 copies of this gene. Male offspring receive 1 X chromosome from their mother and no X chromosomes from their father (instead, they receive 1 Y chromosome from their father), so they have 1 copy of this gene.

There are 2 alleles (forms) of this gene: the red-eye allele (XR) and the white-eye gene (Xr). XR is dominant to Xr, and Xr is recessive to XR. This means an individual with 1 XR and Xr will be red-eyed.

Genotype refers to the combination of alleles an indi­vidual has at a gene. The table lists each genotype and the corresponding eye color.


Students did 4 experiments to investigate the inheri­tance of eye color in fruit flies. In each experiment, 50% of the offspring were females and 50% were males.

Experiment 1
Fifty red-eyed females with Genotype XRXR were mated with 50 white-eyed males. The results were as follows:

Females: 100% red-eyed.
Males: 100% red-eyed.

Experiment 2
Fifty female offspring and 50 male offspring from Experiment 1 were mated together. The results were as follows:

Females: 100% red-eyed.
Males: 50% red-eyed; 50% white-eyed.

Experiment 3
Fifty female offspring from Experiment 1 were mated with 50 white-eyed males. The results were as follows:

Females: 50% red-eyed; 50% white-eyed.
Males: 50% red-eyed; 50% white-eyed.

Experiment 4
Fifty white-eyed female offspring from Experiment 3 were mated with 50 red-eyed males. The results were as follows:

Females: 100% red-eyed.
Males: 100% white-eyed.
questions.question: 7.  To produce only white eyed offspring, one would mate fruit flies with which of the following sets of genotypes?

questions.question: 12.  In Experiment 3, the parents most likely, had which of the following genotypes?

questions.title: Passage Ⅲ
questions.article:
The carburetors in gasoline engines have a constric­tion called a venturi, where gasoline and air are mixed (see Figure 1).


Because the diameter of the venturi is less than the diame­ter of the air inlet, air moves faster through the venturi than through the air inlet. As a result, the pressure in the venturi is less than atmospheric pressure, and gasoline is drawn into the venturi. Moreover, the faster air moves through the venturi, the lower the pressure in the venturi, and the greater the rate at which gasoline is drawn into the venturi.

The percent change in pressure (%△P) can be defined as:


The %△P of carburetors was determined under various conditions in the following experiments.

Experiment 1
A carburetor was mounted on an engine with an air volume capacity (the volume of air drawn into the engine during each piston stroke) of 0.55 liter (L). The %△P of the carburetor was found at various engine speeds. The results are given in Table 1.

Experiment 2
The engine used in Experiment 1 was fitted with car­buretors having the same air inlet diameter as in Experiment 1 but different venturi radii. The %△P for each carburetor was measured at an engine speed of 3,000 rpm (see Table 2).


Experiment 3
The carburetor used in Experiment 1 was fitted to engines having various air volume capacities. The %△P for each engine was measured at an engine speed of 3,000 rpm (see Table 3).
questions.question: 13. Under the conditions described for Experiment 3, a %△P of 2.2 would most likely be obtained if the air volume capacity equaled:

questions.question: 15.  Which  of  the following is the most likely explanation for the results of Experiment 1 ? As engine speed increases, %△P:

choices.A: increases, because air speed through the venturi increases.
choices.B: increases, because air speed through the venturi decreases.
choices.C: decreases, because air speed through the venturi increases.
choices.D: decreases, because air speed through the venturi decrease.

questions.article:
The carburetors in gasoline engines have a constric­tion called a venturi, where gasoline and air are mixed (see Figure 1).


Because the diameter of the venturi is less than the diame­ter of the air inlet, air moves faster through the venturi than through the air inlet. As a result, the pressure in the venturi is less than atmospheric pressure, and gasoline is drawn into the venturi. Moreover, the faster air moves through the venturi, the lower the pressure in the venturi, and the greater the rate at which gasoline is drawn into the venturi.

The percent change in pressure (%△P) can be defined as:


The %△P of carburetors was determined under various conditions in the following experiments.

Experiment 1
A carburetor was mounted on an engine with an air volume capacity (the volume of air drawn into the engine during each piston stroke) of 0.55 liter (L). The %△P of the carburetor was found at various engine speeds. The results are given in Table 1.

Experiment 2
The engine used in Experiment 1 was fitted with car­buretors having the same air inlet diameter as in Experiment 1 but different venturi radii. The %△P for each carburetor was measured at an engine speed of 3,000 rpm (see Table 2).


Experiment 3
The carburetor used in Experiment 1 was fitted to engines having various air volume capacities. The %△P for each engine was measured at an engine speed of 3,000 rpm (see Table 3).
questions.question: 18.  For the carburetors used in Experiment 2 with venturi radii of 0.8 cm, 1.2 cm, and 1.6 cm, which of the fol­lowing graphs best displays the atmospheric pressure at each air inlet and the pressure measured in each venturi?

questions.title: Passage Ⅳ
questions.article:
When substances are heated, they typically expand (increase in volume). Under certain circumstances, some substances will contract (decrease in volume) when heated. Table 1 shows the change in volume that occurred when 1.0000 L samples of solids at different initial temperatures were heated. Tables 2 and 3 show the results for similar trials using 1.0000 L samples of liquids and gases, respectively.

(Note: No phase changes occurred in any of the trials, and the gas samples were heated at constant pressure.)
questions.question: 19.  Which of the following substances listed in Tables 1-3 expanded by the same amount each time it was heated, regardless of its initial temperature?

choices.A: Yes; in every trial that water was heated, the change in volume was positive.
choices.B: No; in every trial that water was heated, the change in volume was negative.
choices.C: Yes; when water was heated from -16°C to 24°C, the change in volume was positive.
choices.D: No; when water was heated from 0°C to 4°C, the change in volume was negative.

questions.article:
As shown in Figure 1, the temperatures of the atmo­spheres of Venus, Earth, and Mars vary with altitude. Figure 1 also shows bow the atmospheric temperature for Earth and Venus varies between day and night and shows the layers of Earth's atmosphere. Table 1 gives the compo­sition of the atmosphere on each planet, both as relative abundance and as the partial pressure, in bars, exerted by each gas at the planet's surface. The total pressure of the gases in Earth's atmosphere at Earth's surface is approxi­mately 1 bar. Table 2 gives what average surface temperatures would be on the 3 planets without greenhouse warming.




Figure and tables adapted from J. Kelly Beatty, Carolyn Collins Petersen, and Andrew Chaikin, The New Solar System, 4th ed. ©1999 by Cambridge University Press.

questions.title: Passage Ⅵ
questions.article:
Nuclear fusion is the combining of the nuclei (central cores) of atoms and can be used to produce energy. Differ­ent nuclei contain various numbers of protons (particles with a single positive electrical charge) and neutrons (uncharged particles).

A containment vessel holds a mixture of deuterium nuclei (containing 1 proton and 1 neutron) and tritium nuclei (containing 1 proton and 2 neutrons). (The density, n, is the number of nuclei/cm3; higher densities increase the frequency of collisions between nuclei.) The nuclei col­lide, fuse, and emit high amounts of energy. Because like­-charged particles repel each other, getting two nuclei close enough to each other to fuse requires that the nuclei be accelerated to high speeds, which consumes energy. Moreover, energy is consumed in preventing the nuclei from striking the walls of the containment vessel, where the nuclei would lose speed.

To produce more energy from fusion than is consumed, the temperature must be maintained above 4 x 107 K for a minimum time, τ, and the product of n and τ must exceed 1014 sec/cm3 (a requirement called Lawson's criterion).

Two methods for confinement (preventing nuclei from colliding with vessel walls) and for producing nuclear fusion are discussed below.

The Magnetic Confinement Method
A magnetic force field compresses a gas of tritium and deuterium nuclei. Because excessive gas densities will cause the magnetic field to buckle, allowing the gas to escape confinement and to strike the walls of the containment vessel, a maximum n of about 1014 nuclei/cm3 is allowed. Therefore, in order to satisfy Lawson's criterion, a temperature of approximately 108 K is maintained for about 1 sec.

The Laser Confinement Method
A pellet containing deuterium and tritium atoms is subjected to pulses of laser Iight, producing a gas with a density of about 1023 nuclei/am3. The laser pulses are shaped to compress and heat the gas to approximately 108 K for about 10-9 sec. Unfortunately, some of the laser energy is reflected rather than absorbed by the gas.

At present, the ratio of power (energy per unit time) produced to the power consumed by the Magnetic Confine­ment Method is higher than that by the Laser Confinement Method. However, because of the very high density of nuclei around the pellet, the power produced by the Laser Confinement Method can be higher than that of magnetic confinement.
questions.question: 29.  Both confinement methods consume large amounts of energy in order to:

choices.C: decrease the speed of the nuclei.
choices.D: decrease the charges on the nuclei.

questions.question: 32.  To increase the probability that nuclei will collide, a goal of both methods is to:

choices.A: decrease the temperature inside the containment vessel.
choices.B: decrease the density of nuclei in the containment vessel.
choices.C: increase the density of nuclei in the containment vessel.
choices.D: increase the number of neutrons in the nuclei.

questions.question: 35.  For a new method of confinement, the product of n and τ is about 1013 sec/cm3. Which of the following changes would be most likely to bring the new method into compliance with Lawson's criterion?

choices.A: A large decrease in n and a small increase in τ
choices.B: A small increase in n and a large decrease in τ
choices.C: Large decreases in both n and τ
choices.D: Large increases in both n and τ
